delivered in the other languages. Corrections should be submitted to original speeches only. They
should be incorporated in a copy of the record and be sent under the signature of a member of the
delegation concerned, within one month of the date of the meeting, to the Chief of the Verbatim

text.i: The meeting was called to order at 3.20 p.m.

page.text: The President: This afternoon, the General Assembly
will consider the reports of the First Committee on agenda
I request the Rapporteur of the First Committee,
Mr. Rajab Sukayri of Jordan, to introduce the reports of the
Mr. Sukayri (Jordan), Rapporteur of the First
Committee: It is my great honour and privilege to present
to the General Assembly the reports of the disarmament
and international security Committee, the First Committee.
The reports of the First Committee under agenda items 57
to 81 are contained in documents A/50/577 to A/50/601,
inclusive. In this connection, I would like to indicate that
corrigenda have been issued to documents A/50/585,
consideration a total of 25 items, which subsumed 21 sub-
items. The Committee concluded its work in 29 formal
meetings and seven informal meetings, in a spirit of
accommodation, despite the number of complex issues with
which the Committee was confronted. Also, with the need
for further rationalization of the work and proceedings of
the Committee in mind, every effort was made to utilize the
conference facilities accorded to the Committee in an
The Committee devoted nine meetings, from 16 to
26 October, to the combined general debate on all
disarmament and international security agenda items. In
order to enhance the effectiveness of its work, the
Committee at this session once again set aside time for a
structured discussion of specific subjects within the
framework of a thematic approach, by holding seven
informal meetings, from 30 October to 3 November 1995.
This phase of the work of the Committee lent a higher
degree of coherence to the discussions and made them
At the current session, the Committee considered a
total of 48 draft resolutions, of which two draft
Convention on the Prohibition of the Development,
Production, Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons
and on Their Destruction", and A/C.1/50/L.15, entitled
"Prohibition of the production of fissile material for
nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices" --
were not pressed to action by their respective sponsors.
Of the draft proposals adopted, 24 draft resolutions and
one draft decision were adopted by the Committee
without a vote; this constituted some 50 per cent of the
During the general debate, Member States raised,
and focused on, a plethora of issues in the field of
international security and disarmament, ranging from the
issue of small arms to the prevention of an arms race in
outer space and from bilateral nuclear arms negotiations
to nuclear-weapon-free zones. However, the following
issues were most widely discussed: The 1995 Review and
Extension Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the
Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) was referred
to by most delegations that participated in the deliberations.
The views on this issue, however, varied, from those who
commended the outcome of that Conference in general
terms to those who addressed a number of specific issues.
Many delegations noted the importance of the indefinite
extension of the NPT as a step which had considerably
enhanced the international nuclear non-proliferation regime.
Many others, however, stressed the fact that the indefinite
extension had not been the only significant outcome of the
Conference. Rather, they drew the attention of the
Committee to such issues as security assurances by nuclear-
weapon States to non-nuclear-weapon States, the necessity
for concluding a zero-yield verifiable comprehensive test-
ban treaty, and the necessity for the immediate initiation
within the Conference on Disarmament of negotiations on
The Committee adopted a draft resolution on the NPT
Conference which took note of the Conference's three
decisions, namely, strengthening the review process for the
proliferation and disarmament; and extension of the Treaty
on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. It also noted
the resolution on the Middle East adopted by the parties to
Other issues that were focused upon during the
discussion included continued nuclear testing by nuclear-
weapon States other than those that still observe a voluntary
moratorium on testing. This constituted one of the most
controversial questions, both during the discussion and later
on during the consideration of and action on draft
Another issue of clear significance within the area of
nuclear weapons was the establishment, or consolidation, of
nuclear-weapon-free zones in the Middle East, South Asia,
Latin America and the Caribbean. In addition, a draft
resolution entitled "Final text of the African Nuclear-
Weapon-Free Zone Treaty (the Pelindaba Treaty)" was
adopted without a vote. The risk of nuclear proliferation in
the Middle East continued this year to be controversial in
spite of the fact that the title as well as the content of the
draft resolution on this subject has this year been
considerably improved with a view to finding consensus
The general debate in the First Committee also
involved such issues as transparency in armaments, where
improving the operation of the United Nations Register of
Conventional Arms. Most speakers regarded the Register
as a necessary and appropriate step towards confidence-
building among States. Various delegations called for the
expansion of the scope of the Register to enable it to
include nationally manufactured conventional weapons as
well as weapons of mass destruction and their delivery
systems. It was noted with regret by some States that the
governmental group of experts entrusted with the
improvement of the Register's operation had last year
issues such as the ongoing Conference on certain
conventional weapons, which is addressing the question
of the Protocol on land-mines; a moratorium on the
export of anti-personnel land-mines; disarmament and
development; a regional approach to disarmament; the
role of science and technology in disarmament; and the
environmental norms in the drafting and implementation
of agreements on disarmament and arms control".
Among the controversial issues tackled by the
Committee this year was that of convening a fourth
disarmament. Views varied concerning, inter alia, a
specific time-frame for that special session, and no
compromise was reached to pave the way for consensus
Finally, it should be noted that this year also the
rationalization of the work of the First
Committee enjoyed the support of delegations, and the
Committee adopted a decision, based on a proposal
introduced by the Chairman of the Committee, to the
effect that consultations aiming at further rationalization
should be continued until the fifty-second session, when
this item would be taken up again by the Committee.
In conclusion, I should like to extend a well-
deserved tribute to all the members of the First
Committee, whose spirit of cooperation and conciliation
made it possible for the Committee to conclude its work
at the current session of the General Assembly one day
I should like to pay a special tribute to the Chairman
of the First Committee, His Excellency Ambassador
impeccable mastery of disarmament and international
security issues and long-term experience in the field of
disarmament and well-known diplomatic skills enabled the
Committee to conclude its work successfully.
I should like to thank the Committee's Vice-Chairmen,
His Excellency Ambassador Antonio de Icaza of Mexico
and His Excellency Ambassador Wolfgang Hoffmann of
Germany, for the excellent manner in which they
discharged the responsibilities entrusted to them. I should
also like to express my appreciation to the Under-Secretary-
General for Political Affairs, Mr. Marrack Goulding, and to
the Director of the Centre for Disarmament Affairs, Mr.
Prvoslav Davinic, for their contribution to the work of the
I also take great pleasure in thanking the Committee
Secretary, Mr. Sohrab Kheradi, whose knowledge and vast
experience in the field of disarmament contributed
immensely to the successful conclusion of the work of the
Committee. I should also like to thank all those who
collaborated with him, including Mr. Sattar, Mr. Alasaniya,
The President: If there is no proposal under rule 66
of the rules of procedure, I shall take it that the General
Assembly decides not to discuss the reports of the First
Committee that are before it today.
The President: Statements will therefore be limited to
recommendations of the First Committee have been made
clear in the Committee and are reflected in the relevant
May I remind members that under paragraph 7 of
"When the same draft resolution is considered in
a Main Committee and in plenary meeting, a
delegation should, as far as possible, explain its vote
only once, i.e., either in the Committee or in plenary
meeting unless that delegation's vote in plenary
meeting is different from its vote in the Committee".
May I remind delegations that, also in accordance with
General Assembly decision 34/401, explanations of vote are
limited to 10 minutes and should be made by delegations
recommendations contained in the reports of the First
Committee, I should like to advise representatives that we
shall take decisions in the same manner as in the First
Committee unless notified otherwise in advance. This
means that where recorded or separate votes were taken
in the Committee, we will do the same.
I would also hope that we may proceed to adopt
without a vote those recommendations that were adopted
without a vote in the First Committee.

page.text: [Subsequently, the delegation of France informed the
Secretariat that it had intended to abstain.]
The President: I shall now call on the representative
of Canada, who wishes to speak in explanation of vote.
Mr. Snell (Canada): In reference to the outer-space
resolution before us, I want to affirm that Canada's
abstention this year does not represent a lessening of our
commitment to ensuring the prevention of an arms race in
outer space. It rather stems from our firm conviction that,
on a priority basis in 1996, the Conference on Disarmament
should focus its resources to the greatest degree possible on
the achievement of an early and successful conclusion of
the negotiations relating to a comprehensive test-ban treaty.
We cannot support, therefore, the establishment of an ad
hoc committee as called for in the resolution.
As the Assembly is aware, over time Canada has been
a strong and constant supporter of the discussions at the
multilateral level in the Conference on Disarmament on
issues relating to arms control in outer space. Canadian
policy in this regard has not changed. It remains firmly
based on the principle that outer space should remain, as it
is now, weapons-free. Activities in the Conference on
Disarmament relating to this objective will continue to
receive our strong and direct support. It is our firm
conviction that, with the successful conclusion of its nuclear
negotiations, the Conference on Disarmament should
return to pursuing its outer-space mandate in succeeding
The President: May I take it that it is the wish of
the General Assembly to conclude its consideration of

page.text: representatives who wish to explain their vote or position
Mr. Felicio (Brazil): I wish to explain my country's
position with regard to draft resolution Q, entitled "1995
Review and Extension Conference of the Parties to the
Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons
(NPT)". This draft resolution appeared in document
Brazil, which is party to the legally binding
commitments related to the non-proliferation of nuclear
weapons in the context of the Treaty of Tlatelolco and
other instruments involving the International Atomic
Energy Agency and the application of safeguards, will not
participate in the vote on this draft resolution since, in my
Government's understanding, it concerns only the States
parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear
I wish to request that Brazil's non-participation be
duly reflected in the record of the vote on this draft
Mr. Dlamini (Swaziland): In this case, too, my
delegation was not able to participate in the decision in
instructions from our capital. I am pleased to announce
that we have now received those instructions.
French): The French delegation would like to recall the
reasons for the vote it is going to cast on draft resolution
A -- document A/C.1/50/L.3 in the First Committee --
entitled "Nuclear testing". We wish to emphasize why we
believe that this text is unfounded, unfair, pernicious and
France supports the conclusion, as early as 1996, of a
comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty. France was the first
among the nuclear-weapon States to advocate the zero
option with respect to nuclear testing -- that is to say, a
stringent test-ban treaty prohibiting all testing of nuclear
weapons or any other nuclear explosions. France welcomed
the fact that most of its nuclear partners rallied to this
demand, and it will continue to pursue this objective.
But, in order to uphold the zero-option objective and
to plead the cause of a comprehensive nuclear-test-ban
treaty, France had to acquire a system to enable it to verify
in the future the reliability of its deterrence capability
without having to carry out any more tests, however limited
In order to acquire this simulation system, which will
prohibit all testing of nuclear weapons or any other nuclear
explosions, France, like other nuclear Powers, had to
complete a very limited nuclear-testing programme.
France will complete this programme in a very short
time, for it is intent on abiding by its commitment with
respect to the conclusion of the comprehensive nuclear-test-
In doing this, France is acquiring the means to
advocate the zero option and is working for a stringent
In doing this, France is respecting its international
commitments. No legal provision, no commitment entered
into by France relates to an "immediate cessation of all
nuclear testing". For three years now, the international
community has been calling on the nuclear Powers to
pledge to exercise the utmost restraint. The series of very
limited tests which is about to be completed is in keeping
with this criterion of utmost restraint.
In doing this, France is not taking any action likely to
damage the environment. Ample evidence has been
provided to confirm this fact. France has displayed
The present draft resolution seems to us very far
removed from the international community's objectives with
respect to disarmament. They are reflected in two draft
resolutions that are before the Assembly today and that in
the First Committee were document A/C.1/50/L.8/Rev.1,
disarmament with a view to the ultimate elimination of
nuclear weapons". These two texts meet all of the
international community's concerns in this field. They are
fundamental texts and France supports them fully.
But the premises of draft resolution A/C.1/50/L.3 do
not correspond to the law as it stands. The commitment
to utmost restraint, adopted as early as 1993 and
confirmed this year, was not and is not a commitment to
an "immediate cessation". The draft resolution has no
Draft resolution A/C.1/50/L.3 calls for immediate
cessation, whereas it is common knowledge that the
objective of our final testing programme serves the
interests of the comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty and
it is common knowledge that this testing programme will
have ended well before the conclusion of that treaty in
1996. Draft resolution A/C.1/50/L.3 is thus unfounded and
The draft resolution mistakenly gives credence to the
idea that the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear
Weapons might not be respected. For this reason, we
This draft resolution is finally rearing its head in
1995, whereas all the parameters relating to the question
of nuclear testing existed in preceding years. But no draft
resolution on the immediate cessation of tests has been
put before the General Assembly in recent years. So why
are we considering this text this year? How could anyone
fail to wonder about the real objectives of this draft
resolution? How could anyone fail to arrive at the
conclusion that there are other motives behind the draft
resolution besides that of promoting nuclear disarmament?
In this respect, we regard the text as unfair.
that this final testing programme would be completed by
the end of February 1996 -- in other words, in a few
The Director General of the International Atomic
Energy Agency has just granted our request to set up an
international committee of experts with the task of
establishing, yet again, that the French tests are not
These two elements, which have arisen since the vote
in the First Committee, must be added to all the others that
militate against the adoption of the draft resolution.
That is why France will vote against the adoption of
this draft resolution. That is why France will continue on its
chosen course. France will have completed the tests in a
comprehensive nuclear-test-ban treaty. France will support
the zero option in the negotiations on that treaty. France
will work for the signing of the comprehensive nuclear-test-
ban treaty in 1996 and will continue to work for non-
Mr. Cassar (Malta): I wish to make a statement in
explanation of vote on the draft resolution, "Nuclear
testing", that appeared in document A/C.1/50/L.3 in the
On the question of nuclear weapons, Malta has a
encouragement and support for all measures aimed at
nuclear disarmament. The States parties to the Treaty on the
Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) have urged
the early conclusion of a comprehensive test-ban treaty.
This policy is an integral part of Malta's overall policy on
disarmament issues, where it is supportive of effective
measures aimed at reducing the level of all armaments.
Malta recognizes and appreciates the endeavours of nuclear-
weapon States towards the promotion of peace and stability.
We welcome the indefinite extension of the NPT and the
nuclear-weapon States' contribution to efforts to reach a
Within this context, Malta has taken positive note of
the solemn announcement made recently by one of the
nuclear-weapon States that its current and last series of
nuclear tests was to be completed by the end of February
1996, well ahead of the initially announced date of 31 May
1996, and of the commitment made by the same nuclear-
weapon State that as from that date it will no longer carry
out any nuclear explosion, even prior to the conclusion and
signing of a comprehensive test-ban treaty. Malta states its
understanding that the current draft resolution is aimed at
the broader issue of nuclear testing.
In casting its vote in favour of draft resolution
A/C.1/50/L.3, Malta would like to express its reservation on
the fourth preambular paragraph. Malta feels that that
paragraph is not a correct reflection of the undertakings by
the nuclear-weapon States at the 1995 Review and
Extension Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the
Malta stresses again its desire for the early
conclusion of a comprehensive test-ban treaty and
acknowledges and welcomes the commitment of all
nuclear Powers to the conclusion of this agreement.

For once, this is indeed a point of order -- order in the

I would therefore like us to be absolutely clear about

A/C.1/50/L.3. This must be stated very clearly by the

I would ask you, Mr. President, if at all possible, to

The Assembly is voting on draft resolution A, entitled

corresponds to the draft resolution contained in document
A/C.1/50/L.3, which was discussed and voted on in the

If any delegation wishes to change its vote, it can do

It is clear that we are voting on the draft resolution

text.i: The draft decision was adopted by 114 votes to 1, with

page.text: representatives who wish to explain their vote or position.
Spanish): The Cuban delegation wishes to explain its
position on resolution 50/70 Q, "1995 Review and
Extension Conference of the Parties to the Treaty on the
Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons", whose adoption
was recommended by the First Committee in its report in
The Cuban delegation voted in favour of this
resolution. In so doing, we bore in mind that it is eminently
factual, taking note of the holding of the 1995 Conference
and of the three decisions and the resolution on the Middle
East adopted there, as well as of the decisions adopted by
the States parties to the Treaty. The Cuban delegation
wishes to state, for the record, that, for these reasons, its
vote in favour of the text should in no way be interpreted
as representing a change in its substantive position on the
question of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear
Weapons, to which my country is not a party, and on which
it has expressed its opinions at the appropriate time.
The President: May I take it that it is the wish of the
General Assembly to conclude its consideration of agenda

page.text: representatives who wish to explain their vote on the
Mr. Rider (New Zealand): New Zealand supported
the resolution we have just adopted under agenda item 73.
We did so because of our concerns about the risk of
nuclear proliferation in the Middle East. We share the
concern that other States parties to the Treaty on the Non-
Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) expressed at this
year's Review and Extension Conference over the
continued existence in the Middle East of unsafeguarded
We reaffirm the importance of universal adherence
to the Treaty and we call on all States in the Middle East
that have not yet done so to accede to the Treaty as soon
We note that the resolution singles out Israel in this
regard. That in our view is inappropriate. As I have
stated, New Zealand calls on all non-NPT parties in the
region, as elsewhere, to join the overwhelming majority
of the international community which see the Non-
Proliferation Treaty as the basis from which we will work

page.text: The President: The Assembly has before it the draft
resolution recommended by the First Committee in
paragraph 8 of its report. It corresponds to draft resolution
In connection with the draft resolution, the Assembly
also has before it an amendment submitted by South Africa
I call on the representative of South Africa to
introduce the amendment contained in document A/50/L.55.
Mr. Burgh (South Africa): The purpose of the
amendment which I am now introducing is merely to
express gratitude to the Secretary-General of the
Organization of African Unity and the Director General
of the International Atomic Energy Agency for their
diligence in assisting the group of experts to prepare a
draft resolution on an African nuclear-weapon-free zone.
This amendment was discussed with the African
Group and also with representatives of other regional
groups, who voiced no objection to the newly inserted
operative paragraph 7. I would therefore urge all members
to support the draft resolution and its amendment so that
it may be adopted by consensus.

I should also like to inform members that on Friday,
